column4: hi i am looking for a good guide on setting permissions related to an apache webserver
can anyone point me in the good direction ?
can't get much better than the apache documentation: http://httpd.apache.org/docs/
i don't understand what you mean by "permissions related to apache", then
apache usually runs as nobody, then it depends how you're going to let users publish documents (ftp uploads? webdav? some kind of php/perl/python script?)
or if not nobody, then at least a user with very few permissions
the general way is to let apache run as whatever user it wants, then make the documents under the web root world-readable so any user (including the one running apache) can read the files
then you can use standard unix users/groups to allow write permissions to the files and folders you want people to upload to
ok, but now my apache is running as user nobody, and i am editing/adding documents as userX
no, just make sure they are world readable (in the drwxrwxrwx permissions, that's the last "r")
setting that bit means that any user can read the files, including apache
you want apache to run as nobody so it has no write permissions to anything, that way if there is a security bug in apache nobody can overwrite your files
